Lots of criticism in the comments (some fair of course), so I wanted to play Devil‚Äôs advocate for a sec. First off, I think we can all agree that going to a party on a boat during a pandemic was a foolish idea; that being said, I think the apology is getting a lot of unfair hate.  This is a fair apology- he‚Äôs admitting he made a mistake and there‚Äôs no excuse for it, he‚Äôs telling everyone what his reasoning was and he‚Äôs acknowledging that he deserves the criticism he‚Äôs getting and that he‚Äôs let people down.  Frankly, if he was just interested in his career as an influencer and not the public health aspect of it, he could have played this a number of ways, he could even have leaned into the controversy like a number of influencers do, but he‚Äôs trying to set the public health aspect of it straight, and that shows a sense of civic responsibility. He‚Äôs saying that critics should attack him and not attack the science - once again, that‚Äôs something.  About the apology sounding written out and rehearsed, of course it must be, these are serious topics and important messages, you can‚Äôt just wing it! Honestly, I‚Äôd be more upset if he hadn‚Äôt planned it beforehand, it would indicate that he wasn‚Äôt taking it seriously enough.  Lastly, on the question of posting this here and not on his main channel, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a cowardly thing, or an attempt to avoid taking responsibility, he‚Äôs probably just trying to limit the number of people who use his bad decision to question the science or deny the pandemic. If people haven‚Äôt heard of the story, voluntarily bringing more attention to it, from a public health perspective, could be even more damaging, since more Covid deniers could jump on the bandwagon and wrongly claim that ‚Äúthis well known Doctor  partied on a boat because COVID is actually a hoax‚Äù. When you think about it, it might have done him personally more good to put the apology on his main channel, as a way to restore face, but he hasn‚Äôt done that because it would be more damaging to the public health effort surrounding fighting the pandemic. That is the ethical decision.  This is a guy who does good as a Doctor and then, in his private time, does good as an influencer - he raises money for charity, he uses his brand to get information out about various organizations and projects and, most of all, he tries to set medical misinformation straight on a relatable level, to get knowledge to the greatest number of people. Was going to a party like this a stupid decision and should he, as a public figure, have anticipated the blowback from the optics? Definitely - It‚Äôs just good sense and a logical degree of self preservation.  But this isn‚Äôt a bad guy or a bad role model. This is a good role model, who made a stupid decision.

So for me, flying is a bit expensive and not really something I can just do when I want, so I thought of this as a more general 'travel', and I would love it if someday either myself or my friends could afford a yatch for a party, but to think of this more relatable I just thought of it as an 'expensive party'. If we are to assume Mike didn't lie in this video, it sounds like he traveled back to his home town where his friends surprised him with an expensive party. Now imagine yourself here, you've been invited to a party thats been set up for *you*, but covid is currently going on. You're hesitant at first cause, well, covid, but your friends tell you that oh, were within max occupancy, and if you think about risk its not too bad. Would you just say "nah" and just let this expensive, already paid party, set up for YOU just go on without you? What difference does one extra person even make?  If we are to believe that he didn't plan this and didn't know about this, then his position is surprisingly relatable. This isn't the person that planned the party and got everyone together, its probably the person that reluctantly agreed (cause its got to be hard to turn down a fancy fun party for yourself, right? oh, and social pressure from your peers), and if he is anything like myself, he would have had this in the back of his mind the whole time. I can sympathise with Dr. Mike. This year has been absolutely awful. I just wonder how many of these commenters would have made the same mistake if they were in Dr. Mike's place? The message is hypocritical, that is true. But hear me out.   I think that this lockdown is unnatural and totally useless. More harmful is the misery that will happen with the economics *after* all is finished. I have heard opinions that we are facing a crash next year because of how the economy has been treated. What we have is a virus that kills people above life expectancy and with an abnormally high infection rate. Is locking everything down worth this? When people look at history, they remember the Great Depression in the 1930s before they remember the Spanish Flu, Polio, trench foot, all the diseases which had to be treated.   I live in Ireland. Our lockdown was practically martial law, we were stuck within the same 5 km radius for six months. We have something now for reporting people who are breaking lockdown laws to the Gardai. We're developing a culture of suspicion. The government here has got a LOT of people furious at them. My entire college degree has been practically broken by this lockdown, I have spent my 21st in lockdown, and I'm expecting to spend my 22nd, 23rd and 24th too, as our world starts to drip feed normality back to us. Meanwhile the super-corporations exploit everything, all the hurt and the pain and only get richer. How many people realise that McDonald's was allowed to remain open, while gyms are closed? This would practically be the setting for a dystopia novel.   I think that it can be established here that this lockdown is not a person's natural state of being (sources: anybody and everybody who is unhappy in lockdown). If anything, I think this highlights the main flaw of this lockdown. Everybody is miserable. Including the doctors. Everybody wants it to end. Dr. Mike has had to be the tip of the spear in how to act, he's been living alone, he's been under pressure from work (even more so than usual) and the news. That creates an opportunity for weakness. Which he took.   In the face of all of this, how many of these commenters would jump onto the chance to have a single break from this lockdown? I believe that there is only so much that a person can care before it gets to this point. Just one party. One night to have time, plus his friends organised that for him. How bad can that possibly be?   I don't believe it is totally fair to believe that the trust Dr. Mike had was broken. He's hardly the Son of God, incapable of making mistakes. He's a human too, and obviously the want for a break got to him. I'd honestly say that it's less of a want and more of a *need.* Sure, he's in control of his actions most of the time. But deny your nature as a person for long enough, and weakness will present itself. Turn it down. Another will appear. Humans are not designed for this lockdown. That's why I feel this lockdown has not worked and will continue to fail. The governments of the world do not seem understand - or care - that humans have a need to be active. So now we have all of the trouble for none of the results.   Admittedly, posting this on the second channel and disabling likes and dislikes only serves him. That was scummy. Also, if you are on the hunt for more members to get the better money income from youtube, then yes, that move was a bad PR, and this apology also wasn't the best one AFAIK, so I'd recommend seeking advice from experts in that field  If your goal isn't any of that, but just to be one of the (many) sources online for sound medical advice based on science, then you haven't failed in that.  You will lose followers, yes. Subscribers who are here for facts? I doubt they care what you do with your health and in your free time.  Sound scientific facts won't become less sound if person quoting them isn't to our liking. Nor will fact become 'more true' if we like the person saying it.  I don't see this any more different as the situation where so many doctors preach health lifestyle to their patients and then go outside for a smoke. It's still a scientifically proven fact that smoking isn't healthy for you. It's still their health and life and their choice what they do.  We live with our choices and their consequences all the time. Covid is different from some other behavior eg 'reckless' driving under alcohol influence, because it's much easier to verify if something bad happened while you were drunk and drove - if you came home safely without any accident, it's easy - you didn't harm anyone. In contrast, covid is more dangerous because if you caught a virus and spread it but you never get sick, some other person still can get sick or even die, and verify that you were the source is hard. There are generally 3 main categories of how we people approach covid situation: - some refuse to be even remotely responsible for someone else's sickness or death, or are afraid of getting sick themselves, and they'll stay at home 24/7 and will disinfect everything and whatnot - others will follow current general guidelines and mostly stick to them, but won't extremely worry if they're the sick one who will infect someone, they hope they won't be the one and will do reasonable things to mitigate the risk, but mostly only if they're asked to do so - some will not care at all neither for themselves nor for others  We all fall somewhere in that spectrum, with giving it more or less thought at any given situation.  For your specific case, covid and boat party, from the covid spread perspective you forgot (to mention) a few things: - maximum allowed people doesn't mean you're allowed to be all in one heap, distance should still be observed, just because law additionally regulates that doesn't mean that virus will say 'oh yeah, it's only 4 of you, I refuse to spread', distance still matters, I only saw a photo of you in a heap style, so yeah, distance fail - being outside is less risky than in closed unventilated spaces, because aerosols become less risky, but droplets are still a factor - yes, masks make virus spread less, so without mask you need even greater distance That is, if you're in the strong middle from list above. In any case, every person involved should be on board with the consequences (you did mention testing before/after, so I guess that was ok)  Btw if you wear masks during travel and work, that means that you care more about protecting all those strangers than protecting your friends :P     There was a meme here in Germany - do my grandkids/kids who visit me during the covid xmas - love me so much or hate me so much? :D

Dr. Mike, you have to know there was a series of unsafe decisions that led to this inappropriate behavior. Risk is indeed a spectrum, and part of that spectrum extends far beyond your individual health. You flew from one COVID hotspot to another, and you state yourself that the destination was your father's home--maybe your personal health isn't of import, but your family's, your friends', and your patients' certainly are, and this compromised their wellbeing unnecessarily. Considering the heart-wrenching decisions my family and my community's had to make, the rifts that have opened up between myself and my loved ones when unsafe actions are taken that force even further isolation in an emotionally fraught and financially precarious time, please ask yourself this: did you have to leave your home right there and then? Did the subsequent choices, one after the other, each provide a benefit that outweighed the cost of a viral super-spreader event; one that almost certainly caused innumerable ripples throughout a suffering country?  We make mistakes. We find ourselves in moments of poor judgment. We can apologize all we like, but we can't undo the harm we've already done. Instead, as it seems you were halfway through doing, we must hold ourselves accountable for the damage, and the best one can do is to find and create whatever positive opportunities can be made from our mistake. You had the right idea of using your mistake as a lesson to be spread to all who spend little thought on the repercussions of similar behavior. However, you could've gone point for point through the poor choices and actions taken, therefore highlighting what should've been done and what alternatives are available for the situation. Further mixed messaging includes the quoted general guidelines not really applying to your specific activities. As for your stated reason behind the recording of your video, the focus edges more on the side of online appearance rather than direct health and safety for all involved. Besides the content of your message, what stands to be the most unfortunate and irreconcilable error is the platform by which you project your message. As an avid viewer of your Doctor Mike channel, it strikes me (and other commenters) that your message is nearly hidden from your channel, so much so that it took months to personally discover your mistake and apology, and it undermines the entire message as a result. You have no links from the main channel to this video, nor to the channel it's hosted on, and there are no videos on your main that could serve as an announcement and/or message boost for this one.  Based on this, how can anyone glean insight from your mistakes, let alone believe your commitment to improved future behavior? The video itself chips away at the apology midway with personal excuses and a reductive explanation that your "personal risk" means you have no need to hold yourself to the same standard as everyone else in your very age group and familial/communal circumstances. Should anyone be expected to walk away from this video with an amended attitude and adherence to CDC guidelines?  This comment may read as harsh. My tone may sound critical. Yet, I must assure you that this comes from a place of not only surprise and pain, but also of respect and admiration. I found your content because I recognized a similar passion for Biology and health. From one researcher to another, it is our responsibility to lead the way to excellence. When we fall, we must rise again with renewed perseverance, with a sense of accountability, and with the foresight of what consequences may result, and thus a response that equally promises and demonstrates the integrity of our fields. It is only through the light of gained wisdom and honesty that we can highlight the path forward for the following generation into an age of prosperity and compassion.  Please, if ever this small voice reaches the appropriate ears, do the ethical thing by linking or uploading this video (with context) to your main channel where more can see and learn from it, and clearly demonstrate what you've preached to your followers in past public health and safety announcements, lessons, and interviews. Dr. Fauci, the CDC, and all of your colleagues rely on your platform to inform and provide for all Americans. There has never been a more crucial time for moral integrity and ethical journalism.

I appreciate Dr. Mike‚Äôs sincerity.  I would like to add that the best guidelines are set by biology.  Not the CDC, not the WHO, not state governments. They offer easily digestible guidelines for the general public.    I honestly expect more from a medical doctor though.  There are a plethora of more variables than those covered by the CDC and WHO organizations.  As a doctor he should be aware of those variables, and included more than just putting himself at risk. He put the rest of the people on the boat at risk.  Masks are absolutely essential in helping prevent the spread of Covid-19..... BUT they don‚Äôt operate in the way that most people think.  Wearing a mask (minus N95 grade or higher) offers minimal protection to the wearer..... the efficacy of transmission prevention comes in when the wearer has Covid-19, and the mask prevents their own Covid-19 carrying water vapor from becoming drastically aerosolized.  Meaning that if a  person has Covid-19, and they are wearing a mask, when that person breathes, or coughs, or sneezes, speaks, etc. the mask tremendously cuts down the exit velocity of said vapors once they leave the wearer‚Äôs mouth hit up against the inside of the mask. THIS is how masks (again, minus N95 and greater) are effective in the prevention of spreading Covid-19.  1. We do not know what type of mask Dr. Mike was wearing.  If he was wearing an N95 or greater, much of what he is saying in this video holds true.   2.  If he was wearing a standard surgical mask, much of what he said in this video is dramatically misleading.  For instance, if he was wearing a mask on that party boat, but there were others who were not wearing a mask, then he is absolutely at risk for contact Covid-19 and then potentially spreading it.   3.  I think it‚Äôs reasonably safe to assume there were beverages and food on the boat.  I think it‚Äôs also reasonably safe to assume people‚Äôs masks came off when they ate or drank something.  During these moments the efficacy of mask wearing and following guidelines obviously becomes terribly reduced. There‚Äôs been a VERY troublesome trend that indicates that a disproportionately high percentage of Covid-19 cases are from people who ate out at a restaurant up to two weeks prior to testing positive for Covid-19.... even though they people *followed* the guidelines while at said restaurant. - - - - Dr. Mike‚Äôs apology is incomplete without addressing such conditions mentioned above.  4.  Dr. Mike‚Äôs safety on that party boat MOSTLY depends on the decisions made by everyone else on that boat.  How strictly were the other people on the boat taking into account the *biological science* of aerosolized viral contagion?  Again, I think it‚Äôs reasonable to assume that there were plenty of lapses in good judgment on the part of most, if not all, individuals on that boat.  Again.... being that Dr. Mike is a medical doctor, he was in a position to educate anyone on the boat who was not familiar with the *biological science* of aerosolized viral contagion. test kits are scarce and rationed in america. so putting yourself in a position where you need testing is also harmful given that it was used to protect a recreational purpose. when people do testing for parties and other recreational activities it reduces the availability of test kits for people that need it, put undue strain on labs and lab workers and reduces the efficiency of testing because it leads to a lag in test results.  one of the ways to combat covid is expediency in testing. the sweet spot for turn around is 48 hours for the gold standard pcr. but when labs are overwhelmed, this is not possible. so sticking to the assurance that everyone was safe and test is STILL a stressor on the system. Testing does not mean your activities had no impact on the pandemic. it did.

I told her I was definitely not planning on going anywhere so she could be honest without worrying it would encourage me to make a bad decision. She said she was having a few people over with strict rules. Everyone from different households was required to stay twelve feet apart. They accomplished this by having her immediate family remain in a room by themselves while the guests were in a large room with furniture spread apart enough for people to be adequately distanced, and they were required to stay sitting except to use the bathroom. Masks were required except when eating, food was left in the doorway where people went up individually to get a plate. This system was also used for exchanging presents. During dinner the windows were opened until everyone put their masks back on. I'm guessing they ate pretty quickly since it was cold outside. Also, COVID rates were not out of control at that point where we live, she's tested on a regular basis, and she had already switched most of her patients to telemedicine appointments. I still think it was a little hypocritical and irresponsible since she's a doctor, but she arranged her gathering so that it wasn't much riskier than a Zoom party and she didn't lose my respect and trust. I know you're embarrassed - and you should be.. but if you want people to respect and trust you..  this looks more like an, "I'm sorry I got caught and now people may not take the precautions seriously," than simply being sorry.  If you're truely worried about the possible repressions of people actually getting sick and dying because of what they saw you do - you need to own up to it on your main channel.  Stop trying to be perfect.  Be human.  Someone who doesn't always think things through and do the right thing.  No "buts".  Any apology with a but in it isn't an apology.  And the absolute LAST thing you should do is misrepresent guidelines to serve your purpose.  If you get water sprayed on you and your mask on a boat, you change your mask & let it dry.  If you jump in the water, take it off, keep your distance, then put it back on.  You know these things.  You found loopholes - not guidelines.  Don't pull out the letter of a guideline & knowingly ignore its intent.  Honestly, that's what bothers me the most.  I believe you did take all the precautions to visit your Dad.  But, even if he isn't taking proper precautions.. the risk wasn't from you to people on the boat.  It was, what if one of them was asymptomatic and now your Dad was dead from your actions?  Would you truely be able to live with yourself?  I had a chance to leave an outbreak area and visit my Grandmother in a nursing home before she died (surprise cancer).  I knew they'd be told to shut down visitation in the next couple days.. but they didn't have that information yet.  I could have hopped on a direct flight and walked right in.  I CHOSE not to.  I knew that just because my Grandma was dying, didn't mean everyone else there was.  If they'd gotten a Covid outbreak - I would have known it came from me, because the area hadn't had even one case yet.  I would have been just as responcible for killing those people as the virus.  And I wouldn't be able to live with knowingly being that selfish.  That's what it means to make sacrifices for others when that's what you believe in.  So, while I have empathy for you - I don't have sympathy.

Hey Dr Mike, you're doing good. You're ok. It's tough. I work in front line healthcare too. I had a very bad experience during April where a covid test delayed some emergency surgery I needed. I went septic and was very close to dying because surgeons literally refused to operate without a negative result. I was negative, but it was 18 hrs of agony as I bleed internally while waiting. My doctor recently saw me face-to-face for the first time since April. He said he felt the situation amounted to malpractice, because of the terrible physical and psychological state it left me in. I lost my job as I couldn't function,  and had to go on disability due to the unnecessary delay. At one point I had contemplated suicide, I was so ruined from the sepsis damage. I've gone clinically deaf and suffer neuropathy. I'm in my 30s. But to hear what the Dr said made me feel valid. I had said my care was awful, but people shut me down for crying ill of the health service during the pandemic. Like I was some spoiled child. Since then, others have bashed my Dr for low-key criticising the NHS during covid. But he is right, and I for one was glad to hear it said. I managed to go back to working in the NHS part-time. I'll never let it happen to someone else with me on the job! We're all under mental stress. Some worse than others. Some pay a price for covid, despite not having it. I followed the rules, I saved the public. I still serve. It's a crises. It's hard. Humans did this to me "because" of covid. Frankly there are things WORSE than covid, but no one gave me the choice to take that risk. I paid the price to save strangers. I'll pay for the rest of my life. I wish the surgeon had analysed the risk in context: I'm young, I live alone, I had no covid symptoms. I used to be so fit. I needed surgery immediately. But covid came first... We're all human. Mistakes are made. You have to move on. All of you. If I can, you can.  RIP old me.

Due to the social impact and people's reactions, he's apologizing for the choices leading to the impact... but being in a country right now that has legally enforced no social contact between non household members (schools and workplaces are open, but no classmates/coworkers outside of class or work and Christmas... canceled) I understand the spike in suicidality and other difficulties in many people during this time due to prolonged hypervigilance and separation. To have some rare legal in person connection with loved ones is not something people should be crucified over, especially when following the CDC's guidelines. There is no doubt Dr Mike has made a major mistake. What really gets me annoyed is that I really feel that his apology is not so much as an apology and more of a statement of damage control. I can completely give Dr Mike another chance on the mistake side of things as I have made mistakes aswell and so have all of you. Where I really struggle is with this video. I will give you a very personal example, in 2014 I went to a friend's birthday party I had just taken 2 months off work to relax as it had been a challenging year so I was not seeing patients for another two months. Whilst at that party I made a bad decision and used an illicit substance ( Cocaine ) as far as I was aware no one saw me do it or had any idea but the very next day I felt so bad that I self reported myself to the AMA and was given a warning. My colleagues were not told but I addressed them in private to inform them so they could learn from my mistakes and many of them admitted to me of making similar mistakes themselves. Now if Dr Mike had not of been called out would he have made this public ? I don't think so. Would he have protected his image and financial situation above his integrity Im not sure but I'm suspicious he would have. I think we should be able to forgive Dr Mike for his mistake but until he shows that he has really accepted responsibility for it we should not forget it. I honestly think when you examine your own risks and make decisions like this the important thing is to keep tabs on your symptoms and the people that you were with so you don't potentially spread to someone who could get seriously hurt by catching it. My practice during lower numbers and openings was to not do multiple things or see multiple people within a 2 week period at the very least. If anything were to happen then I'd have a simple job tracking my activity and who I was exposed to. As a doctor I'm sure that for every serious case he's seen hundreds of mild ones too, I don't blame him for referencing guidelines and enjoying some companionship within the realms of recommendations. I get he's put on a pedestal and needs to uphold a standard for others, but I'm tired of seeing people isolate to the point of hurting themselves without using some common sense. There are ways you can protect yourself and others and still have necessary connections. If you see someone and get exposed make sure your activity following potential exposure would result in a quarantine without a laundry list of potential places you spread it in between. If catching it at all is risky for you, avoiding those who haven't been isolated and tested negative is ideal, but please don't say 100% isolation is the end-all solution. It's not, because it presents other types of risks, like neglect of mental health and overlooking individuals trapped in abusive situations or facing health risks from delayed response to stroke, heart attack or asthma. Connections are important, just be mindful and take care of yourselves. Stay healthy and safe üíï

No hate, no place to get attacked, your vulnerability is safe with those you trust. Being on the internet is so totally different than being in real life - it's its own challenge. It is of such high value to recognize: a) he made his decision carefully - making the best choice possible b) the choice for him is not the same as the choice in his online role model c) he did wrong in his online function d) he takes full responsibility for his bad choice e) he tries to do as good as he can and acknowledges his mistake but not let it defeat him. What is happening in this comment section:  Women are introduced to Doctor Mike. He's well-spoken, tall, handsome, a doctor and compassionate. He seems like the perfect man. What happens now is that they forget that he is human. Because he is the ideal man in some aspects they believe that Doctor Mike has every trait they think the ideal man would have, based on their own views and beliefs about reality. Then something like this happens and it fractures their idea of who they thought Doctor Mike is. They now feel anger at Mike for doing what they think of as the "wrong thing". The anger stems from the fact that their perception of Doctor Mike was wrong, most of the anger isn't actually because of his actions.

Hi Dr. Mike, I'm also an early career physician. I think your message is ultimately a good one. Thank you for your public discussion and apology. I was disappointed when I saw the pictures, because it flies in the face of all we are working for, for our patients and for public health. However, being Internal Medicine/Geriatrics, and dealing with some COVID+ patients as a PCP and in the hospital... I also think healthcare practitioners are under enormous, endless stress right now, so I get the "wanting to just forget COVID for a minute, be with friends, have some fun and feel normal for a second" mentality.   However, as you recognize now, that just can't really happen. Whether this is lip-service, or you actually get it, only you know. What we have to practice what we preach, and really live the message, live by example. Hopefully your message is genuine, and I want to believe it is. I wish like Dr. Mike that people wouldn't use his "big oops" as a reason to throw in the metaphorical towel, however. He's human, he messed up, and he learned a lesson of fame this month. But folks, let's also remember the Fundamental Attribution Error. It is way way more likely that he is in a bad situation, rather than being a "bad guy". It's like healthy living -- diet and exercise -- just because you have cake or skip a few days of running does NOT mean the whole thing is a loss. You just pick yourself back up and try harder the next time. So keep masking up, social distancing, and washing those hands. We are all in this together, and one of our own, Dr. Mike had a stumble. So we help him back up, and help him to do better next time. Just like we'd want someone to do for us.  And we ABSOLUTELY DO NOT make his mistake a soundbite for a warped anti-mask, COVID-is-hoax agenda. That is never okay, and that is where the irreparable public and personal health harm comes from -- not one bad idea boat trip. Let's raise people up, not drag people down. Keep fighting, y'all. :)

But far worse than that is the moment mask mandates are put in place and everyone is wearing them, REGARDLESS of how much you reiterate social distancing is a must, people WILL feel safer, and NOT make social distancing a priority, when that and THAT alone has been the most provable link to the spreading of this and any other "airborne" virus.  If you want to wear a mask, and it makes you feel better, great, if you get some unintentional placebo effect, again, great, but don't tell others they are endangering others, that they are inconsiderate and a conspiracy theorist.    The actual, long term, randomly controlled trials are there, the data from dozens of states post mask mandates are there.  They don't support significant reduction in transmission or acquisition.  I have lost so much respect for people I used to think highly of during this pandemic, because their desire to stay relevant, their desire to not be deplatformed rises way above their desire to be honest, and shoot straight. Lastly, the fact that the only level of masks that will protect you, such as P100 masks are categorized as "not recommended" should be the biggest red flag that these people don't care about you being safe, and simply want compliance.  If you want to actually be safe via a mask, wear a P or N 100 respirator.  That's it.  If you wear a surgical mask, you might as well have nothing on your face. If you wear "triple layer" cloth mask you won't bode much better, and if you are wearing an N/P/R 95 you better know how to wear it and remove it, and never touch it while between those 2 points.

I'm disappointed and torn between viewing you as bad or good.  First: This should have been posted as a video on your main channel. When making an apology, you should choose to do it where more people can see it. That way, your acknowledgment of your wrongs would be shown more publicly. On the other hand, I can imagine comments that are all like: "You're just attention-seeking." or something else of the sort if you were to post it on your main channel, so I'm not sure about that.   Second: While yes, your getting on the boat could have been acting on impulse, your traveling to Miami, was not. I'm not happy about that. My grandparents in China are old and are on their last legs. I would give everything to see them in person one more time, but I don't go, even though it could be the last time I ever see them. Yes, obviously, China had the greatest numbers at one point, but my point is, you chose to go to a densely populated city for seemingly no reason and chose to party. Once again, this could be explained away as wanting to have fun, but, like you said, it was extremely irresponsible and never should have done. I have had times where I know that I shouldn't do something, but still plan it anyway, and still carry it out, and then regret silently until someone finds out, so I know the feeling. The issue now is that your actions hurt a lot more people than my silly ones about buying too many things or something.   Third: Your apology sounds very scripted. This isn't necessarily a bad thing unless it was something that someone wrote for you for damage control. If I were to issue an apology video (I hope I will never have to do something like that), I would also be scripting my reply because I find it much easier to organize my thoughts if I write them on paper. It would lead to a more cohesive video instead of nervous stammering and cuts. Then again, if it's scripted, certain feelings can be faked, so it seems very insincere.   Fourth: You only apologized because you got caught. I agree here. But once again, I don't know if I would consider this a bad thing or a neutral thing. On one hand, apologizing only because you got caught can seem like damage control and can seem like you don't really care about what you did. On the other hand, no one knows what was going on inside your head. Like I said in my second point, I've done things that I planned for, despite knowing they were horrible ideas and still carried through with them. I also didn't apologize right away, and I wouldn't have apologized unless I got caught. I can't stand criticism (and yes, I recognize that I could have avoided some criticism if I apologize right away) to the point that if I even get the slightest amount, I get sent into an anxious and depressive state for several days at a time. Just because I don't apologize until I get caught doesn't mean I don't regret what I did. I usually do, and I spend the many, many days after that constantly regretting what I did. So that's another thing I'll have to give a pass on.   Overall, I'm still very disappointed. I understand that you're human, and that you make mistakes, but I don't know if I'll ever be able to trust you completely after this. The research and rules you put out are very valid and do help. However, I just really hate that you weren't able to follow through with them with all of us. I thought we were in this together, but I don't know anymore. I'm sorry Dr. Mike

Almost a day ago, I posted a comment about this situation (kind of a long winded one) and said that he should be ashamed. It got 2 likes and no comments. "So what" you may ask, "what did you expect?" Well, I expected more. Why? Because as an experiment, I reposted the comment about 12 hours later, when the video had made its way farther down the trending page and was receiving less attention. That repost received over 100 comments and 5 replies in half the time it took the other to get just 2. Could this be coincidence, maybe. But I decided to check. A few hours after I posted the original comment, I went looking for it in an incognito window. I went to the time when I posted it by sorting the comments. Low and behold, there was nothing. I went a full HOUR farther back than I originally posted it, I went over it all again, and I even refreshed the page 3 times. The comment still showed up on my channel, just not on this one. Please don't talk about difficult times like you understand what people are going through. My grandmother died earlier this year and because of the strict guidelines set in my country (the UK) hardly anyone was allowed to attend. I was lucky to be able to say my goodbyes. However her own sisters, brothers and grandchildren were not permitted to attend. We were not allowed to host her funeral in a church like planned because the lockdown closed all churches. So instead of us saying our goodbyes inside of her favourite church, it was in a cold, empty room in a funeral home. Instead of the whole family celebrating together to honour her memory and life, we had to go home alone. We could not hug eachother for support or even sit next to eachother at the service. We all did our part to reduce the spread and risk, despite losing our most treasured family member.   I do not care for your individual risk, I don't care for mine. But I care for others. I'm young and healthy but I can still be affected and I can affect others. You are a doctor, take responsibility and act like a decent one. Who cares if you're not at risk, other people are. At times like these people must stick together and fight to carry on. You may have no risk but your patients do. You're a family physician, think of the child with asthma, the mother with heart disease or the father with COPD. Be selfless, not selfish. Your behaviour, your choices and your actions, affect everyone around you now. A 22 year old woman should not be given you this advice, you should already know. Unfortunately people overestimated you.   You are a privileged, healthy, white man. You're extremely lucky, but with the choices you made your luck will start to run out. The nurses in my hometown are exhausted, completely drained of life because they work tirelessly night and day trying their very best to save lives. 18 hour shifts with no rest, struggling to help the amount of people suffering. Food trucks being used to transport dead bodies, their co workers dying from the virus and watching people day in and day out suffer the same fate.   Think of these people next time you decide to be selfish. We are all trying our best, we have all suffered in some way. You are no different. I sincerely hope this mistake you have made has been a hurtful kick in the gut. I hope you learn and change your ways not just for you or your reputation but for the people you are risking. May this experience humble you and make you human. Be the support people need and for godsake do not pass blame for this. This is your wrong doing, nobody else's. Own it and be a decent person in the future.   *A sidenote for anyone reading who has lost someone, or their job, home, can't be with loved ones, is isolated, suffering with mental or physical health. I hope things get better for you, for all of us and I hope we can continue to support eachother best we can. Stay safe.

) A seminar about the Chinese communist regime's organ pillaging from prisoners of conscience was held at the General Post Office Building in Helsinki, Finland on September 18, 2019.  Supporting Human Rights in China (SHRIC) hosted the seminar, and the speakers included independent investigator and human rights lawyer David Matas; senior investigative reporter Ethan Gutmann; Enver Tohti, a former surgeon from Xinjiang, China who witnessed doctors remove an organ from a living person; and Dr. Marja Heinonen-Guzejev, a public health researcher at the University of Helsinki.  Chinese Medical Papers Rejected for Failing to Explain Organ Sources Dr. Marja Heinonen-Guzejev spoke at the seminar on behalf of Physicians for Social Responsibility (LSV), a Finnish medical association that aims to promote health and equality in Finland and around the world. She said the ethical issues surrounding organ transplantation in China have drawn attention from international scientific circles.   Dr. Marja Heinonen-Guzejev talked about the ethical issues regarding organ transplantation in China.  Dr. Heinonen-Guzejev explained that two scientific publications, Plus One and Transplantation, deleted 15 scientific papers from China this August because the researchers couldn't explain the sources of organs used in their research.  According to the British Medical Journal, the authors of more than 400 scientific papers from China couldn't explain the sources of human organs used in 92 percent of their medical cases.  Dr. Heinonen-Guzejev said that Spain, Israel, Italy, Norway, and Taiwan have prohibited their citizens from going to China for organ transplantation.  Organs Taken from Living People Dr. Enver Tohti is a former Uyghur surgeon from China who now lives in London. He said the Chinese regime has treated about a million Uyghur prisoners as living ‚Äúorgan donors,‚Äù just as it does to Falun Gong practitioners.  He noted that patients in China have to wait only a week to obtain a matching organ. He also showed a picture of a special lane at an airport in China that is specifically used for transporting organs that have been taken from living people. The audience was shocked to hear that Hunan Provincial People's Hospital had once run promotional ads offering 20 kidney transplantation operations for free.

We have been in a global pandemic for almost 10 months now. I think there is a side of everyone that is experiencing the pandemic fatigue and it's resulting in questionable decisions.  I've been pretty good with the whole pandemic, ordering my groceries, limiting contact, social distancing, zoom calls to connect with friends. "A total of 3030 participants were randomly assigned to the recommendation to wear masks, and 2994 were assigned to control; 4862 completed the study. Infection with SARS-CoV-2 occurred in 42 participants recommended masks (1.8%) and 53 control participants (2.1%). The between-group difference was ‚àí0.3 percentage point (95% CI, ‚àí1.2 to 0.4 percentage point; P = 0.38) (odds ratio, 0.82 [CI, 0.54 to 1.23]; P = 0.33). Multiple imputation accounting for loss to follow-up yielded similar results. Although the difference observed was not statistically significant, the 95% CIs are compatible with a 46% reduction to a 23% increase in infection."  0.3% infection rate difference between masked and unmasked in randomized controlled trial with 6,000 participants.  Src: acpjournals. org/doi/pdf/10.7326/M20-6817  ‚ÄúThe analysis included 2314 healthy contacts of 672 index case patients with Covid-19 who were identified between March 17 and April 28, 2020. A total of 1116 contacts were randomly assigned to receive hydroxychloroquine and 1198 to receive usual care. Results were similar in the hydroxychloroquine and usual-care groups with respect to the incidence of PCR-confirmed, symptomatic Covid-19 (5.7% and 6.2%, respectively; risk ratio, 0.86 [95% confidence interval, 0.52 to 1.42]). In addition, hydroxychloroquine was not associated with a lower incidence of SARS-CoV-2 transmission than usual care (18.7% and 17.8%, respectively). The incidence of adverse events was higher in the hydroxychloroquine group than in the usual-care group (56.1% vs. 5.9%), but no treatment-related serious adverse events were reported.‚Äù  6% attack rate when living with family (where you‚Äôre in close proximity & sharing everything). I can therefore conclude the masks are a negative contributing factor to my overall health. If a reasonably healthy, even if overweight, 30 something has caught one or two colds/ bugs lasting 3-5 days per month (not aligned with menstruation symptoms) when previously I only got sniffles at seasonal changes, and I am no longer in as microbial rich an environment as Kindergarteners singing followed by splattered trumpet and saxophone juice, and the only other factor is a cotton mask that traps such microbes against my facial orifices... it doesn't make sense to me why we're risking our breathing quality and overall health to a disease many people are overcoming. I am in no means down playing the severity of Covid, what I had in March was an awful week (less juicy than Swine Flu though).
